screenplay.rawText:
INT. DRUNKEN ART CRITIC PODCAST STUDIO – DAY
Jason appears as a guest on Martin Jenkins' podcast. A large segment of dialogue unfolds as Martin drinks progressively more wine, critiques Jason’s work harshly at first, then reveals a reluctant appreciation. The commissioned painting hangs behind them.
actions: Jason sits beside MARTIN JENKINS, aka The Drunken Art Critic.
Jason’s newly completed commissioned painting hangs between them on the set wall.
Martin checks with his producer off-camera, still prepping despite claiming he isn’t ready.
Martin pours wine for Jason, then for himself.
Martin launches into the interview, already half-snarky and half-buzzed.
Martin critiques the painting as 'jejune' before acknowledging he often says that when drunk.
Jason explains his Illustrated Abstractions style.
Martin grows steadily more intoxicated, philosophizing about the death of tactile art forms.
The conversation ends with Martin surprisingly complimenting both Jason and the painting.

lines: Are we ready?... I’m not quite ready.
Cheers.
Lovely, that’ll do for now.
We’re rolling?
Today I’m sitting with Jason Towne. Welcome to the show Jason.
Yes, yes of course. We’re going to have a few drinks together, and discuss some art—your art.
Fantastic! Let’s talk about some art and life.
I have to say it’s a bit jejune.
You know, naive. Simple. Superficial.
Well, it’s only paint and canvas. What else could it be?
Indeed...
Yes, well, I say jejune when I’m drunk. So pardon me for that.
In your opinion, is painting a dying art form?
I’m referring to the death of everything tactile. We live in a world of screens now.
Take this wine as an example: You cannot enjoy this through a screen.
Of course I hope you’re right about that.
One more thing—I usually become more discontented with my guests as the show unfolds. However, you are not as egregious as most.
Yes, in other words, you’re not remarkably bad.
I’ve quite enjoyed our little chat.
This has been fun for me, this wine is fantastic.
That is all for now... The bar is closed... for you anyway. Ha!
Yes. And don’t forget to read my next article, it publishes soon in Art Knowing Magazine. Bye bye for now.
Cheers.
Hi Martin, thanks for having me.
Love it, that’s why I’m here.
Sounds great, I’m familiar with your show. Seems to be working well for ya.
Come again?
Sure, in that context it is simple. It is paint on canvas.
It seems appropriate to call these illustrated abstractions...
I stack line-work onto expressive brush strokes that are layered onto a colorfield base.
I hope not. Haven’t people been saying that for the past 100 years?
You’re right, I think people will always make their way back to the tactile world.
Egregious? Thank you... I guess.
I’ll take that as a compliment.
Well, thanks for having me.

narrative.summary: Jason participates in the Drunken Art Critic podcast, where Martin Jenkins delivers a mixture of drunken insults, philosophical musings, and surprising compliments. The interaction showcases both Jason’s calm grounded nature and the bizarre, chaotic world of art media Franklin has pushed him into.
narrative.beatPurpose: Marketing Event #1; deep character contrast between Jason’s sincerity and the chaotic, performative art-world commentator.
narrative.conflict: Comic verbal conflict—Martin challenges Jason’s work aggressively before softening.
narrative.stakes: Jason’s reputation is being publicly shaped. This podcast will influence the art show and his standing with the mysterious buyer.
narrative.outcome: Jason handles the interview with grace. Martin ends up supporting him, promising a future article.
themes: The absurdity of the art world
The evolution (or death) of tactile creativity

emotionalShifts.Jason Towne: Relaxed → Defending his work → Mildly amused → Confident
emotionalShifts.Martin Jenkins: Pretending professionalism → Increasingly drunk → Critical → Philosophical → Warm

locations: Drunken Art Critic podcast studio set
continuityLinks: This is Marketing Event #1 in Jason’s contract.
Leads directly into upcoming Marketing Event #2 (dangerous neighborhood photoshoot with Kenny).

music: Loose jazz or comedic, off-kilter background cue to underscore Martin’s drunkenness

Slow zoom on Jason as Martin insults the painting
